After the warmest six month period in history, lake effect season got off to a quick start about a week earlier than normal.  A sharp cold front moved across the region during Monday evening the 5th and lake plumes developed off Lake Erie prior to dawn of the 6th. Several inches fell by mid-morning across Chautauqua and northwest Cattaraugus counties. There were some power outages reported as the trees were still full-leafed and the weight of the snow snapped limbs.  An approaching upper level trough broke up the band as it lifted north of the area. Total snowfall accumulations of eight inches were reported from Mayville, South Dayton and Ellicottville.

A low pressure system that passed just south of Lakes Michigan and Erie helped produce the first measurable snow of the winter season for the higher terrain of the Poconos. Rain began during the afternoon of the 9th and precipitation changed to snow over the higher terrain during the late evening of the 9th. Light snow continued through the night and ended during the morning of the 10th. Accumulations over the higher terrain averaged around one inch.  The low pressure system moved from Ohio on the morning of the 9th into western Pennsylvania on the evening of the 9th. A second low pressure system formed well east of the Delmarva Peninsula the same evening. The primary low pressure system stalled and dissipated in western Pennsylvania overnight as the secondary low slowly intensified and moved farther offshore. By the morning of the 10th, this low pressure system was well southeast of Cape Cod, Massachusetts.

An area of low pressure moved from the northern Plains on November 17th toward the Mid Atlantic States on the 18th, with a warm front draped from Ohio to southern Delaware. Another area of low pressure however developed off the coast of Virginia during the 18th and then moved out to sea on the 19th and into the 20th. A surface trough however bridged the two areas of low pressure. Meanwhile, an upper-level low tracked across the upper Ohio Valley and right across Pennsylvania late on the 19th, however it was weakening with time. This brought accumulating snowfall to parts of northern New Jersey. This storm was elevation dependent, as temperatures in the lower elevations were above freezing by a couple of degrees during most of the event. The storm system gradually moved off to the east on the 19th, bringing an end to the widespread precipitation.| |The steady snow began falling over the higher terrain of northwest New Jersey around Midnight EST on the 19th. The first widespread snow event of the 2007-08 winter season affected south-central and southeast Wisconsin on November 21st.  Snow accumulations were in the 1 to 3 inch range.  Media reports indicated that dozens vehicle accidents occurred.  Temperatures were in the upper 20s to lower 30s and the snowflakes were large and moist.  Maximum accumulations included 3 inches in southern Sheboygan County, northeastern Washington County, and from north of Elkhorn in Walworth County to central Waukesha County.  Otherwise the remainder of south-central and southeast Wisconsin had 1 to 2.5 inches.  Initially, the precipitation started off as rain, but changed over to snow between 1600CST and 1700CST west of Madison and between 1800CST and 1900CST in the Sheboygan to Kenosha area.  Synoptically, a strong, upper-level short wave trough moving from Colorado to Illinois was responsible for the snow.  Additionally, southern Wisconsin was under the right-rear quadrant of a 140 knot jet streak over the Great Lakes region.  This is a favored region of lift/upward vertical motion.

Another swath 15 to 30 miles wide of 3-inch plus snowfall fell from Hays south through eastern Rush County and continued in the Larned, Kinsley and St. John areas.  One to two inches were reported across the rest of the CWA.

A quick moving 500mb shortwave swept across the Central Plains and deposited the first measurable snow across northeast Kansas overnight November 23 through the morning hours of November 24th. The snow generally began around 9pm CST over north central Kansas and spread eastward over the course of the next hour, before ending between 5 and 6am CST across the region. Accumulated snowfall totals were generally light, and ranged from one half of an inch to one inch across portions of Jefferson, Shawnee, and Lyon Counties, to around 1 to 3 inches across counties further north and west in the Topeka Coutny Warning Area. But, this first snowfall of the season occurred the weekend after the Thanksgiving holiday, and numerous car crashes were reported across the area as a result of the slick conditions established by the wintry precipitation.  At least one stretch of I-70 in Topeka was shut down for 90 minutes to clear the scene of an accident.

A dry cold front dropped south through California November 21st, ahead of an upper-level trough that arrived the next day. A very cold airmass moved into inland Central California during the 21st-22nd, bringing the first hard freeze of the season to the Kern County deserts.  Low temperatures bottomed out at 23 degrees at Edwards Air Force Base).  During the early morning hours of November 24, frost occurred across portions of the San Joaquin Valley floor, as a result of the same cold airmass.  Low temperatures dipped to 27 near Wasco and Gustine, and 28 at the Coalinga Airport.||The upper-level trough dropped into the Great Basin early on November 23rd, while high pressure moved into southern Idaho. This resulted in a northeast wind flow over the Southern Sierra Nevada. Strong winds developed over the Sierra Nevada crest near Yosemite National Park, with the highest wind gusts of this event occurring at Tioga Pass, reaching 74 mph at 8:00 AM PST on November 23. Other wind gusts were measured between 40 to 55 mph through the Southern Sierra Nevada and locally in the Sierra Nevada Foothills as well, such as in the Mariposa area where 2 trees were downed and blocked Road 222.  This Mono wind event also toppled numerous trees in Yosemite National Park, and blocked Tioga Pass Road as well.

This was the first big snow event of the winter season, and it was a Colorado Low. These are traditionally bigger snow producers for the northern plains than Alberta Clippers or hybrid low pressure systems. This system was no exception, as it dropped from 6 to 11 inches of snow over southeast North Dakota and portions of west central and northwest Minnesota. Wind speeds gusted to 30 mph frequently from Saturday evening (1st) into Sunday morning (2nd), producing blowing and drifting snow and visibilities less than a quarter mile at times in exposed areas. With the warm ground temperatures, surfaces did become slick. The highest snow total, 11 inches, occurred at Wadena, Minnesota. This event began late on November 30th and continued into the first part of this month. Since many drivers were not accustomed to winter driving yet, there were quite a few vehicle accidents.

By the end of the event, ice accumulations of a quarter to half inch accumulated, causing hazardous conditions. The heaviest accumulations occurred across the southeastern half of Holt county where ice accumulations of a half inch were common.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to one half of an inch of ice accumulated on bridges and roads across the county.
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm system brought a round of freezing rain and drizzle to locations mainly north of Interstate 35 early the morning of December 1st. Around one quarter of an inch of ice accumulated in portions of north central Kansas, before near surface temperatures rose above freezing after sunrise. I began to accumulate on vehicles and structures around 2am, and on roadways by around 4am.  Slick spots were reported by local law enforecement on several roads across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One quarter of an inch of ice had accumulated in the Haddam area. Up to an eight of an inch of ice was reported to have accumulated on vegetation and vehicles elsewhere across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first major winter storm of season coated south central Nebraska with a treacherous blanket of ice during the morning hours of December 1.  The freezing rain resulted in a wide array of travel problems for the area. The heaviest ice accumulations, in the neighborhood of one half inch, occurred mainly along and north of Interstate 80. However, there were several reports of a coating of one-quarter to one-half inch of ice down to the Kansas border. There were reports of sporadic power outages and tree damage throughout the area. Many events scheduled for Saturday, December 1st were postponed. Fortunately, warmer air surged north and changed the freezing rain to rain by late morning, and also allowed for some of the ice to melt.

High pressure moved into central and southern California during the first few days of December, resulting in a period of abnormally cold temperatures. Frost and freeze conditions were reported across much of the San Joaquin Valley durings the mornings of the 1st and 2nd. The coldest temperatures occurred on the morning of the 2nd, when readings bottomed out in the mid 20s at locations such as Collins Corner, Hanford, Los Banos, Orosi, Allensworth, Alpaugh, and Lemoore Naval Air Station.
